concept.Definition: Concept is the name of the root entity in the Quranic ontology. All other concepts and subcategories in the ontological hierarchy are organized under the root concept.

artifact.Definition:
Artifact is a category that refers to man-made constructions that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

astronomical-body.Definition:
Astronomical Body is a category that refers to astronomical objects that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

event.Definition:
Event is a category that refers to temporal events.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

false-deity.Definition:
False Deity is a category related to the worhsip of false gods mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

holy-book.Definition:
Holy Book is a category that refers to holy books and other religious texts that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

language.Definition:
Language (لغة) is a category that refers to the languages mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

living-creation.Definition:
Living Creation is a category that refers to the living creations of Allah that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

location.Definition:
Location is a category that refers to places and other locations that are mentioned by name in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

physical-attribute.Definition:
Physical Attribute is a category that refers to the attributes of physical objects.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

physical-substance.Definition:
Physical Substance is a category that refers to physical substances mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

religion.Definition:
Religion is a category that refers to the major relgions, or other systems of ancient belief, that are mentioned by name in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

weather-phenomena.Definition:
Weather Phenomena is a category that refers to the different types of weather phenomena that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

allah.Definition:
Allah (الله) is the name in the Quran used for the one and only true God, in accordance with the monotheistic nature of Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

allah's-throne.Definition:
Allah's Throne (العرش) is mentioned in several verses of the Quran, and is also known as al-kursi.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

place-of-worship.Definition:
Place of Worship is a category that refers to places of worship that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

weaponary.Definition:
Weaponary is a category that refers to weaponary mentioned in the Quran, although these instruments may also have other uses.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ark-of-the-covenant.Definition:
Ark of the Covenant (تابوت العهد) is mentioned in the Quran to contain artifacts from the household of Musa (Moses) and Harun (Aaron).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

boat.Definition: Boat (سفينة) is one of the man-made artifacts mentioned in the Quran.

coin.Definition:
Coin (دَراهِم) is one of the man-made artifacts mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ink.Definition:
Ink (حبر) is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

key.Definition:
Key (مفتاح) is mentioned in several verses of the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ladder.Definition:
Ladder (سلم) is mentioned in the Quran, and is also translated into English as "stairway".
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

lamp.Definition:
Lamp (لمبة) is mentioned in several verses of the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

noah's-ark.Definition:
Noah's Ark (سفينة نوح) is mentioned in the Quran as a sign of Allah.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

pen.Definition:
Pen (قلم) is mentioned in several verses of the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ship.Definition:
Ship (سفينة) is one of the man-made artifacts mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

constellation.Definition: Constellation (البروج) is one of the astronomical objects mentioned in the Quran, although the Arabic term is also translated into English as "great stars".

earth.Definition:
Earth (أرض) is mentioned in many verses of the Quran as the dwelling of humanity in the worldly life.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

moon.Definition:
Moon (القمر) is one of the astronomical objects mentioned in the Quran, usually referred to along with the Sun.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

sirius.Definition:
Sirius (الشِّعرى) is one of the astronomical objects mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

star.Definition:
Star (نجم) is one of the astronomical objects mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

sun.Definition:
Sun (الشمس) is one of the astronomical objects mentioned in the Quran, usually referred to along with the Moon.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

afterlife-event.Definition:
Afterlife Event is a category that refers to events in the afterlife.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

calendar-event.Definition:
Calendar Event is a category in the ontology which refers to recurring events in the Islamic calendar, or to other religious calendar events mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

historic-event.Definition:
Historic Event is a category that refers to historic events mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

physical-event.Definition:
Physical Event is a category that refers to temporal events mentioned in the Quran, that naturally occur in the physical world.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

idol.Definition:
Idol (الأصنام) is a category which refers to idols and other false objects of worship, that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

al-uzza.Definition:
Al-Uzza (العزى) is the name of a false pre-Islamic goddess mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

allat.Definition:
Allat (اللات) is the name of a false pre-Islamic goddess mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

baal.Definition:
Baal (بعل) is the name of a false deity mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

manat.Definition:
Manat (مناة) is the name of a false pre-Islamic goddess mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

nasr.Definition:
Nasr (نسر) is the name of a false deity mentioned in the Quran, who was worshipped at the time of the prophet Nuh (Noah).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

suwa.Definition:
Suwa (سواع) is the name of a false deity mentioned in the Quran, who was worshipped at the time of the prophet Nuh (Noah).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

wadd.Definition:
Wadd (واد) is the name of a false deity mentioned in the Quran, who was worshipped at the time of the prophet Nuh (Noah).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

yaghuth.Definition:
Yaghuth (يغوث) is the name of a false deity mentioned in the Quran, who was worshipped at the time of the prophet Nuh (Noah).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

yauq.Definition:
Yauq (يعوق) is the name of a false deity mentioned in the Quran, who was worshipped at the time of the prophet Nuh (Noah).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

injeel.Definition:
Injeel (الإنجيل) is the name of the holy book revealed by God to Jesus, according to Islamic belief.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

quran.Definition:
Quran (القرآن) is the central religious text of Islam, written in Quranic Arabic.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

torah.Definition:
Torah (التوراة) is the name of the holy book of law given by God to Musa (Moses), according to Islamic belief.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

zabur.Definition:
Zabur (زبور) is the name of the holy book revealed by God to David (the Book of Psalms), according to Islamic belief.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

arabic.Definition: Arabic (العربية) is mentioned by Allah to be the language in which the Quran was revealed, and is the language of the Arabs.

organic-object.Definition:
Organic Object is a category that refers to organic objects and other biological entities.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

sentient-creation.Definition:
Sentient Creation is a category which refers to the angels, jinn, humanity and other sentient creations mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

afterlife-location.Definition:
Afterlife Location is a category that refers to locations in the afterlife.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

geographical-location.Definition:
Geographical Location is a category that refers to geographical locations mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

color.Definition:
Color (لَون) is a category that refers to the the different colors that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

metal.Definition:
Metal is a category that refers to the types of metal that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

mineral.Definition:
Mineral is a category that refers to the different minerals that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

clay.Definition:
Clay (صلصال) is the substance that man was originally created from, according to the Quran and Islamic belief.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

coral.Definition:
Coral (مرجان) is one of the precious materials mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

dust.Definition:
Dust (تراب) is one of the physical substances mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

glass.Definition:
Glass (زجاج) is one of the materials mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

oil.Definition:
Oil (زيت) is one of the physical substances mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

pearl.Definition:
Pearl (لؤلؤ) is one of the precious materials mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

silk.Definition:
Silk (حرير) is one of the precious materials mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

soil.Definition:
Soil (ثرى) is one of the physical substances mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

christianity.Definition:
Christianity (النصارى) is one of the major religions mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

islam.Definition:
Islam (الإسلام) is the monotheistic religion based on the Quran and the teachings of the prophet Muhammad.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

judaism.Definition:
Judaism (اليهود) is one of the major religions mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

magians.Definition:
Magians (المجوس) are one of the religious groups mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

sabians.Definition:
Sabians (الصابئين) are one of the religious groups mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

cloud.Definition: Cloud (سحاب) is one type of weather phenomena mentioned in the Quran.

lightning.Definition: Lightning (برق) is one type of weather phenomena mentioned in the Quran.

rain.Definition:
Rain (مطر) is one type of weather phenomena mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

thunder.Definition:
Thunder (رعد) is one type of weather phenomena mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

mosque.Definition:
Mosque (مسجد) is a category that refers to mosques mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

church.Definition:
Church (كنيسة) is one of the places of worhsip mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

monastery.Definition:
Monastery (صوامع) is one of the places of worhsip mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

synagogue.Definition:
Synagogue (صلوات) is one of the places of worhsip mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

arrow.Definition: Arrow (سهم) is mentioned in the Quran in the context of divining arrows, which are prohibited according to Islamic law.

coat-of-mail.Definition: Coat of Mail (سابغات) is mentioned in the Quran as having been constructed by the prophet Dawood (David) from iron, to use as armour.

knife.Definition:
Knife (سكينة) is mentioned in the Quran in the story of the noble prophet Yusuf (Joseph).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

day-of-resurrection.Definition:
Day of Resurrection (يوم القيامة) is the time in the afterlife when Allah will resurrect and judge humanity.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

last-day.Definition:
Last Day (اليوم الآخر) is a name mentioned in the Quran that refers to the Day of Resurrection.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

friday.Definition:
Friday (الجمعة) is the day of the week in which the Jumu'ah prayer is performed (the Friday prayer).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

hajj.Definition:
Hajj (حج) is the pilgrimage to Makkah and one of the five pillars of Islam. The pilgrimage occurs during the 12th month of the Islamic calendar.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

night-of-decree.Definition:
Night of Decree (ليلة القدر) is the night in the month of Ramadan in which the Quran was revealed to the prophet Muhammad (also known as the Night of Power).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ramadan.Definition:
Ramadan (رمضان) is the sacred month of fasting in the Islamic calendar, and the month in which the Night of Decree occurs.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

sabbath.Definition:
Sabbath (السبت) is a day of the week that was specified in previous revelations before the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

umra.Definition:
Umra (عمرة) is a pilgrimage to Makkah that may be performed at any time of the year.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

al-jahiliyah.Definition:
Al-Jahiliyah (الجاهلية) is the pre-Islamic time of ignorance.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

dawn.Definition:
Dawn (فجر) is mentioned in several verses of Quran, usually in the context of worshipping Allah.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

golden-calf.Definition:
Golden Calf (عجل الذهب) is mentioned in the Quran, and refers to the false idol worshipped by the Israelites during Moses' absence.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

biological-organism.Definition:
Biological Organism is a category that refers to biological organisms that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

body-part.Definition:
Body Part is a category that refers to the parts of livings things that are mentioned Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

disease.Definition:
Disease is a category that refers to diseases mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

food.Definition:
Food is a category that refers to foods mentioned in the Quran, and includes both lawful foods as well as foods that are prohibited according to Islamic law.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

alaq.Definition: Alaq (علق) is usually translated into English as a clinging substance or clot, and refers to an early stage in the development of the embryo in the womb.

embryo.Definition:
Embryo (أجنة) is one of the stages of human development mentioned in the Quran, although the Arabic term used is also translated into English as "fetus".
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

angel.Definition:
Angel (الملائكة) is a category in the ontology which refers to the creations of Allah mentioned in the Quran known as angels. According to Islamic belief, the angels were created from light in an analogous way to how the jinn were created from fire, and man from clay.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

children-of-adam.Definition:
Children of Adam (بنى آدم) is an alternative name mentioned in the Quran that refers to humanity, the descendents of Adam.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

human.Definition:
Human is a category in the ontology which refers to individual human beings or groups of people mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

jinn.Definition:
Jinn (الجن) is a category in the ontology which refers to the creations of Allah mentioned in the Quran known as the jinn.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

beast-of-the-earth.Definition:
Beast of the Earth (دابة الارض) is mentioned in Quran. The nature of the beast is further explained in the hadith of the prophet Muhammad.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

firdous.Definition:
Firdous (الفردوس) is one of the names of Paradise mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

garden-of-eden.Definition:
Garden of Eden (جنات عدن) is the name of a place of everlasting bliss in afterlife.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

hell.Definition:
Hell (جهنم) is the place of punishment and torment in the afterlife.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ladha.Definition:
Ladha (لظى) is one of the names of Hell (Jahannam) mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

lote-tree.Definition:
Lote Tree (السدرة) is a location in the afterlife that is mentioned in the Quran, and is usually considered to be part of Paradise.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

paradise.Definition:
Paradise (الجنة) is the place of reward and peace in the afterlife.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

salsabil.Definition:
Salsabil (سلسبيل) is the name of a fountain or spring, that the Quran mentions as being located in Paradise.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

saqar.Definition:
Saqar (سقر) is one of the names of Hell (Jahannam) mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

sijjeen.Definition:
Sijjeen (سجين) is a name used to refer to both a record of evil deeds, as well as part of Jahannam (Hell).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

zaqqum.Definition:
Zaqqum (زقوم) is the name of a tree, that according to Islamic belief grows in Jahannam (Hell).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

city.Definition:
City is a category that refers to cities mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

historic-land.Definition:
Historic Land is a category that refers to ancient lands and other historic locations mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

mountain.Definition:
Mountain is a category that refers to the mountains and other small mounts that are mentioned by name in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

desert.Definition:
Desert (صحراء) is one of the geographical locations mentioned the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

horizon.Definition:
Horizon (أفق) is one of the geographical locations mentioned the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

qiblah.Definition:
Qiblah (قبلة) is the direction of prayer in Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

green.Definition:
Green (أخضر) is one of the colors mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

brass.Definition:
Brass (مهل) is one of the types of metal mentioned in the Quran, although the Arabic term used is also translated into English as "copper" or "oil".
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

gold.Definition:
Gold (ذهب) is one of the types of metal mentioned by name in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

iron.Definition:
Iron (حديد) is one of the types of metal mentioned by name in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

silver.Definition:
Silver (فضة) is one of the types of metal mentioned by name in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ruby.Definition:
Ruby (ياقوت) is one of the precious minerals mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

kaaba.Definition:
Kaaba (الكعبة) is located in the main mosque in Makkah, Masjid al-Haram. Literally "the cube", the kaaba is the current qiblah - the direction of prayer in Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

masjid-al-aqsa.Definition:
Masjid al-Aqsa (المسجد الأقصى) is a sacred mosque in Jerusalem, considered to be the third holiest place in Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

masjid-al-haram.Definition:
Masjid al-Haram (المسجد الحرام) is the main mosque in Makkah. Surrounding the kaaba, it is the largest mosque in the world and the holiest place in Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

animal.Definition:
Animal is a category which refers to animals mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

bird.Definition: Bird (طائر) is one of the creations of Allah mentioned by name in the Quran. This category in the ontology includes the general concept of birds, as well as specific types of bird mentioned in the Quran.

insect.Definition:
Insect is a category that refers to insects that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

plant.Definition:
Plant is a category that refers to plants that are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

fish.Definition:
Fish (حوت) are one of the creations of Allah mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

bone.Definition: Bone (عظم) is mentioned in the Quran most often in reference to man being resurrected after becoming dust and bones.

ear.Definition:
Ear (أذن) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

eye.Definition:
Eye (عين) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

finger.Definition:
Finger (أصابع) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

forehead.Definition:
Forehead (جبهة) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

forelock.Definition:
Forelock (ناصية) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

heart.Definition:
Heart (قلب) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

heel.Definition:
Heel (كَعب) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

intestine.Definition:
Intestine (أمعاء) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

lip.Definition:
Lip (شفة) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

snout.Definition:
Snout (خرطوم) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

tongue.Definition:
Tongue (لسان) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

wing.Definition:
Wing (جناح) is one of the parts of the body mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

leprosy.Definition:
Leprosy (الأبرص) is one of the diseases mentioned in the Quran in the context of the miracles of the noble prophet Jesus, son of Mary.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

bread.Definition: Bread (خبز) is one of the foods mentioned the Quran.

carrion.Definition:
Carrion (الميتة) is one of the prohibited foods mentioned in the Quran (the remains of dead animals).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

grain.Definition:
Grain (حبة) is one of the foods mentioned the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

honey.Definition:
Honey (عسل) is one of the foods mentioned the Quran as a sign of creation.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

meat.Definition:
Meat (لحم) is one of the foods mentioned the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

milk.Definition:
Milk (لبن) is one of the foods mentioned the Quran as a sign of creation.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

pork.Definition:
Pork (لَحم الخنزير) is one of the prohibited foods mentioned in the Quran (the flesh of swine).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

salt.Definition:
Salt (ملح) is mentioned in the Quran as one of the signs of creation, in the context of the division of the seas into freshwater and saltwater.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

wine.Definition:
Wine (خمر) is one of the prohibited foods mentioned in the Quran, along with other intoxicants.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

azrael.Definition:
Azrael (عزرائيل) is the name of the angel of death, according to general Islamic belief, although the name Azrael is not mentioned explicitly in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

harut.Definition:
Harut (هاروت) is the name of an angel mentioned in the Quran, who together with Marut went down to the ancient city of Babylon.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

jibreel.Definition:
Jibreel (جبريل) is the angel of revelation (also known as Gabriel) who recited the Quran to the prophet Muhammad.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

malik.Definition:
Malik (مالك) is the name of an angel mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

marut.Definition:
Marut (ماروت) is the name of an angel mentioned in the Quran, who together with Harut went down to the ancient city of Babylon.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

mikaeel.Definition:
Mikaeel (ميكائيل) is the name of an angel mentioned in the Quran (also known as Michael).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

historic-people.Definition:
Historic People is a category that refers to ancient nations, tribes and other groups of historic people mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

historic-person.Definition:
Historic Person is a category in the ontology which refers to individual historic people mentioned by name in the Quran, or who are well-known in Islam.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

king.Definition:
King (ملك) is a category that refers to kings who are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

messenger.Definition:
Messenger is a category that refers to the messengers of Allah mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

prophet.Definition:
Prophet is a category that refers to the prophets of Allah mentioned in the Quran.

iblis.Definition:
Iblis (إبليس) is another name for Satan (the devil) who was the jinn that refused to prostrate before Adam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

satan.Definition:
Satan (الشيطان) is the devil in Islamic theology, and is a jinn also known as Iblis.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

babylon.Definition: Babylon (بابل) is mentioned in the Quran. An ancient city in Mesopotamia (c. 3000 BC), Babylon is widely considered to be the cradle of civilization.

badr.Definition:
Badr (بدر) is the name of a city in Arabia mentioned in the Quran, at which an early Islamic battle took place.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

bakkah.Definition: Bakkah (بكة) is another name for the holy city of Makkah (Mecca).

hunayn.Definition:
Hunayn (حنين) is the name of a city in Arabia mentioned in the Quran, at which an early Islamic battle took place.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

iram.Definition:
Iram (إرم) is the name of a place in ancient Arabia mentioned in the Quran (also known as Iram of the Pillars).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

makkah.Definition: Makkah (مكة) is the holiest city in Islam (also known as Mecca) and is located in the Hijaz region of Arabia.

medinah.Definition:
Medinah (المدينة المنورة) is a holy city in Islam (also known as Yathrib) and is located in the Hijaz region of Arabia.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

yathrib.Definition:
Yathrib (يثرب) is another name for the holy city of Medinah.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

al-ahqaf.Definition:
Al-Ahqaf (الأحقاف) is a historic region mentioned in the Quran that refers to the curved sand dunes in the southern part of the Arabian peninsula.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

egypt.Definition: Egypt (مصر) is a land mentioned in the Quran that refers to what is known today as Ancient Egypt.

sheba.Definition: Sheba (سبأ) is an ancient land mentioned in the Quran that was ruled over by Balqis, the Queen of Sheba.

al-judi.Definition:
Al-Judi (الجودي) is the mountain on which Noah's Ark came to rest after the great flood.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

al-marwah.Definition:
Al-Marwah (المروة) is a small mountain outside Makkah which together with Al-Safa is visited during the Hajj pilgrimage.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

al-safa.Definition:
Al-Safa (الصفا) is a small mountain outside Makkah which together with Al-Marwah is visited during the Hajj pilgrimage.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

mount-arafat.Definition:
Mount Arafat (عرفات) is small mountain outside Makkah which is visited during the Hajj pilgrimage.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

mount-sinai.Definition:
Mount Sinai (طور سيناء) is the name of a mountain mentioned in the Quran which is on the Sinai peninsula in Egypt.

breast-bone.Definition:
Breast Bone (الترائب) is mentioned in the Quran, although in the verse that the Arabic word occurs, this term is also often translated into English as "ribs".

aad.Definition:
Aad (عاد) are a historic people mentioned in the Quran who were sent the prophet Hud.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ansar.Definition:
Ansar (أنصار) are mentioned in the Quran, and were the citizens of Medinah that helped the prophet Muhammad during the migration from Makkah (literally, "the helpers").
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

bedouin.Definition:
Bedouin (أعراب) are mentioned several times in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

children-of-israel.Definition:
Children of Israel (بنى إسرائيل) are mentioned in the Quran when referring to the Israelites. According to Islamic belief, the twelve tribes of Israel are the descendents of Yaqub (Jacob, also known as Israel), who was the son of Isaac.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

companions-of-the-cave.Definition:
Companions of the Cave (أصحاب الكهف) are a group of people whose story is recounted in the chapter of the Quran named "The Cave".
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

companions-of-the-elephant.Definition:
Companions of the Elephant (أصحاب الفيل) are a group of people whose story is recounted in the chapter of the Quran named "The Elephant".
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

companions-of-the-pit.Definition:
Companions of the Pit (أصحاب الأخدود) are a group of people who are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

companions-of-the-rass.Definition:
Companions of the Rass (أصحاب الرس) are a group of people who are mentioned in the Quran (also known as the companions of the well).
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

companions-of-the-wood.Definition:
Companions of the Wood (أصحاب الأيكة) is a name used in the Quran to refer to a group of people from the nation of Shuayb.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

gog-and-magog.Definition:
Gog and Magog (يأجوج ومأجوج) are a group of people mentioned in the Quran who are kept behind a great wall.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

madyan.Definition:
Madyan (مدين) is the name of a people mentioned in the Quran who were sent the prophet Shuayb.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

people-of-al-hijr.Definition:
People of al-Hijr (أصحاب الحجر) are a group of people who are mentioned in the Quran, as an alternative name for the people of Thamud.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

quraysh.Definition:
Quraysh (قريش) is the name of the tribe to which the prophet Muhammad belonged.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

romans.Definition: Romans (الروم) are an ancient people who are mentioned in Quran, in verse (30:2). A chapter of the Quran is also named after the Romans.

thamud.Definition: Thamud (ثمود) is the name of a people mentioned in the Quran who carved stone houses out of mountains in ancient Arabia. They were sent the prophet Salih.

tubba.Definition:
Tubba (تبع) are an ancient people who are mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This category is part of the following classification in the ontology:

abel.Definition:
Abel (هابيل) is the brother of Cain and son of Adam. The story of Cain and Abel is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

azar.Definition:
Azar (آزر) is mentioned in the Quran as the father of Ibrahim (Abraham).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

cain.Definition:
Cain (قابيل) is the brother of Abel and son of Adam. The story of Cain and Abel is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

dhul-kifl.Definition:
Dhul Kifl (ذو الكفل) is a righteous man who some Muslims also consider to be a noble prophet, altough this is not mentioned explictly in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

dhul-qarnayn.Definition:
Dhul Qarnayn (ذو القرنين) is righteous ruler mentioned in the Quran who constructed a wall to hold Gog and Magog. His story is recounted in the chapter of the Quran named "The Cave".
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

haman.Definition:
Haman (هامان) is the name of the chief minister of the Pharaoh at the time of Musa (Moses).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

imran.Definition:
Imran (عمران) is known in the Quran as the father of Maryam (Mary).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

jalut.Definition:
Jalut (جالوت) is also known as Goliath, and is mentioned in the Quran as being the leader of an army. He was killed by the prophet David (Dawood).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

luqman.Definition:
Luqman (لقمان) is the name of righteous and wise man mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

maryam.Definition:
Maryam (مريم) is the mother of Jesus and son of Imran, and is one of the most highly regarded women in Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

pharaoh.Definition:
Pharaoh (فرعون) is the name of the ruler of ancient Egypt at the time of the story of Musa in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

qarun.Definition:
Qarun (قارون) is the name of an Israelite mentioned in the Quran who turned against Musa (Moses).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

samiri.Definition:
Samiri (السامرى) is mentioned in the Quran as the one who turned against Musa (Moses) and misled people to worship the golden calf.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

talut.Definition:
Talut (طالوت) is the name of one of the Kings of the Israelites (also known as Saul) who is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

uzair.Definition:
Uzair (عزير) is the name of a historic person mentioned in the Quran (also known as Ezra), who according to Islamic belief used to be falsely called "the son of God".
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

elijah.Definition:
Elijah (إلياس) is a noble prophet in Islam whose name is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

hud.Definition:
Hud (هود) is a noble prophet in Islam (also known as Eber) who was sent to the people of Aad.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ibrahim.Definition:
Ibrahim (إبراهيم) is a noble prophet in Islam (also known as Abraham), the son of Azar and the father of Ishmael and Isaac.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ishmael.Definition:
Ishmael (إسماعيل) is a noble prophet and messenger in Islam and the first born son of Ibrahim.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

jesus.Definition:
Jesus (عيسى) is the son of Mary and a noble prophet and messenger in Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

lut.Definition:
Lut (لوط) is a noble prophet in Islam who was sent by God to warn his people to turn away from evil acts.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

muhammad.Definition: Muhammad (محمد) is the name of the last prophet and messenger of Allah.

musa.Definition:
Musa (موسى) is a noble prophet in Islam, who's name occurs more frequently in the Quran than any other prophet or messenger.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

nuh.Definition:
Nuh (نوح) is a noble prophet in Islam who is mentioned in the Quran to have lived to around 950 years in age, at the time of the great flood.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

salih.Definition:
Salih (صالح) is a noble prophet in Islam who was sent to the people of Thamud.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

shuayb.Definition:
Shuayb (شعيب) is a noble prophet in Islam who is considered by many to be synonymous with the Biblical figure of Jethro.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

yunus.Definition:
Yunus (يونس) is a noble prophet in Islam whose story with the fish is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

adam.Definition:
Adam (آدم) is the first man created by God, the first prophet in Islam and father of Cain and Abel.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ahmad.Definition:
Ahmad (أحمد) is one of the names of the noble prophet and messenger Muhammad.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

ayyub.Definition:
Ayyub (أيوب) is a noble prophet and messenger in Islam (also known as Job) who is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

david.Definition:
David (داود) is a noble prophet in Islam, who is known as Dawood in the Quran, and is the father of Solomon.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

elisha.Definition:
Elisha (اليسع) is a noble prophet in Islam whose name is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

harun.Definition:
Harun (هارون) is a noble prophet in Islam the younger brother of Musa.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

idris.Definition:
Idris (إدريس) is a noble prophet in Islam (also known as Enoch) whose name is mentioned in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

isaac.Definition:
Isaac (إسحاق) is a noble prophet in Islam, the second son of Ibrahim and the father of Yaqub (Jacob).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

israel.Definition:
Israel (إسرائيل) is the name of the noble prophet Yaqub (Jacob) that is used when referring to the Israelites, known as the Children of Israel in the Quran.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

messiah.Definition:
Messiah (المسيح) is a name used in the Quran for Jesus.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

solomon.Definition:
Solomon (سليمان) is a noble prophet in Islam who is known as Sulayman in the Quran, and is the son of David.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

yahya.Definition:
Yahya (يحيى) is a noble prophet in Islam (known in the Bible as John the Baptist) and is the son of Zechariah.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

yaqub.Definition:
Yaqub (يعقوب) is a noble prophet in Islam, the son of Isaac and father of Yusuf (Joseph).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

yusuf.Definition:
Yusuf (يوسف) is a noble prophet in Islam and one of the sons of the prophet Yaqub (Jacob).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

zechariah.Definition:
Zechariah (زكريا) is a noble prophet in Islam and father of Yahya (John). Zechariah was also the guardian of Maryam (Mary).
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

abu-lahab.Definition:
Abu Lahab (أَبو لهب) is mentioned by name in the Quran as a condemned enemy of Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

umm-jamil.Definition:
Umm Jamil (أم جميل) is the wife of Abu Lahab, and is referred to in the Quran as an enemy of Islam.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:

zayd.Definition:
Zayd (زيد) is mentioned by name in the Quran and was the adopted son of the prophet Muhammad.
				
				This concept is part of the following classification in the ontology:
